Following up on a previous discussion on solving
Tic-Tac-Toe, I wanted to open up to the group the
question of the rule base for optimal play.

I tried to find an optimal rule base on-line (thinking
this would be an easy thing to find)...but no dice.

Here's the rule base (or very close to it) that we're
using for our "Best" player:

1. If you have a winning move, make it (if more than
one exists, make the first you find)
2. If opponent has a winning move, block it (if more
than one exists, block the first you find)
3. If the center is open, play there
4. If your opponent makes a forking move, in opposite
corners with your piece in the center, play a random
edge to threaten.
5. Play in a random corner.
6. Play on a random edge.

So does a player that follows this rule base play
"optimal" Tic-Tac-Toe (if "optimal" is defined as
winning if at all possible, and playing to a tie when
not)?

In looking around, I found another student paper that
defined optimal play as never losing, much like
Joseph's paper.  But a rule set for such a player
would not necessarily resemble the rule set above.  It
would primarily be concerned with blocking winning
moves and preventing opponent forks (moves which
create two possible win threats).

Ken suggested testing a perfect player by constructing
all possible game states, and making sure the neural
net player makes an optimal move for each possible
board configuration.

But how to you determine what optimal is, without
empirical tests?

When I put two Random players against each other, the
results fall out like this:

Player 1 wins: 45%
Player 2 wins: 45%
Ties: 10%

When I play a "Best" player, using the rule set above,
against a Random player, I get:

Best wins: 90%
Random wins: 0%
Ties: 10%

Is there a way to mathematically determine the correct
ratio of W/L/T between an optimal player and a random
one?

Derek
